Selected Answer: B
A resource monitor can help control costs and avoid unexpected credit usage caused by running warehouses. A virtual warehouse consumes Snowflake credits while it runs. You can use a resource monitor to monitor credit usage by virtual warehouses and the cloud services needed to support those warehouses. You can also set up a resource monitor to suspend a user-managed virtual warehouse when it reaches a credit limit.
B. Resource Monitor
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
B. Resource Monitor

questions.question_text: Which object allows you to limit the number of credits consumed within a Snowflake account?
When cloning a database, what is cloned with the database? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Existing child objects within the database
choices.C: Future child objects within the database
choices.D: Privileges on the schemas within the database
choices.E: Only schemas and tables within the database

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
A. Privileges on the database -- This is not correct as source for cloning do not inherit privileges 
B. Existing child objects within the database --- This is correct
C. Future child objects within the database --- This is not correct
D. Privileges on the schemas within the database Most Voted -- As Schema is child, it inherits all grants
E. Only schemas and tables within the database --- This is not correct
A and B are Correct
Correct Answer: BD

Selected Answer: BD
B and D are correct
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/object-clone
only B is correct. Grants are only inherited if Copy Grants keyword is used while creating a clone.

Selected Answer: BD
Correct
BD is correct answer

BD. If the source object is a database or schema, the clone inherits all granted privileges on the clones of all child objects contained in the source object.
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/object-clone.html#cloning-and-governance-objects

Selected Answer: BD
child objects grants are cloned

Selected Answer: BD
Database itself plus all child objects. Not the grants on the database itself, but the grants on the child objects are preserved.
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/object-clone.html#access-control-privileges-for-cloned-objects

Selected Answer: BD
All objects and grants are cloned except on the clone level (in this case database)

Selected Answer: BD
B, D

For D: If the source object is a database or schema, for child objects contained in the source, the clone replicates all granted privileges on the corresponding child objects

https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/object-clone.html#access-control-privileges-for-cloned-objects

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
“Bytes spilled to remote storage” indicates the volume of data that couldn’t fit in memory and had to be spilled to a virtual warehouse temporary storage.
D.is correct
Correct Answer: D
Correct Answer: D

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
Answer should be D

Selected Answer: D
For some operations (e.g. duplicate elimination for a huge data set), the amount of memory available for the compute resources used to execute the operation might not be sufficient to hold intermediate results. As a result, the query processing engine will start *spilling* the data to local disk. If the local disk space is not sufficient, the spilled data is then saved to remote disks.
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/ui-query-profile.html#queries-too-large-to-fit-in-memory

questions.question_text: When reviewing a query profile, what is a symptom that a query is too large to fit into the memory?

choices.B: Partitions scanned is equal to partitions total
choices.D: The query is spilling to remote storage
choices.A: A single join node uses more than 50% of the query time
